messages: e17b312664dc52de1e9263d94f8d4a5d (08:44): how do i switch the field order of a table...
e17b312664dc52de1e9263d94f8d4a5d (08:44): so its alphabetical and i can import my data
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (08:55): how do I do this?  select (2*2) as four, (four*four) as sixteen
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:07): cekc: Derived tables.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:08): cekc: SELECT (four*four) as sizteen FROM (SELECT (2*2) as four) v1;
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:11): cekc: MySQL 4.1 or better required for that.
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:11): Error 124, Every derived table must have its own alias
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:12): cekc: It does if you use my example.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:12): cekc: Notice the v1.
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:14): ah!  The v1 wrapped to the next line in my irc clieint
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:16): widescreen?
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:17): Pivots as you wish.
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:17): what are those letters after the queries for?  I noticed that mysql query client will sometimes add an "m" or other letters at the end
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:17): cekc: Which letters?
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:18): cekc: That's the derived table alias.  I could have refered to v1.four
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:18): cekc: SELECT (v1.four*v1.four) as sixteen FROM (SELECT (2*2) as four) v1;
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:19): SELECT * FROM someTable m
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:19): what does the m mean
c3293d9d27408395cf6ff549f809c7ff (09:19): it's an alias
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:19): cekc: it's a table alias.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:19): cekc: Derived or not.
c3293d9d27408395cf6ff549f809c7ff (09:19): useful for if you need to refer to a specific table twice in a query.
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:20): so instead of v1 I could put anything else?

d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:21): cekc: It can be also be useful while designing a query, when you don't actually know the contents of the derived table and you don't want to impact the outer expressions when changing the contents of the derived tble.
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:21): ah, so the alias is not any of the original tables, it's the table that is output by the query
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:22): cekc: You know you want xyz, but don't know the table or derived table you will use.  Just ... SELECT v1.xyz FROM (...) v1 ...;
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:22): I'll have to read up on this some more
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:23): The same holds for... SELECT t1.xyz, ... FROM some_unknown_table t1 JOIN ...;
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:23): You can change the unknown table without changing anything else, as long as the fiedl name remains.
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:25): why is the table unknown?
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:25): ah I get it

d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:26): cekc: When I help people here, I sometimes have to create sample tables.  Later the person might hand me the real tables.  I can just insert the final table names without touching the rest of the query, since I use aliases for everything.
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:35): how many of those froms can I stack up?
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:38): ooooooo...    select (sixteen*sixteen) as twofiftysix from (select (four*four) as sixteen,four from (select (2*3) as four) luke) yoda
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:41): cekc: luke and yoda are slipping.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:42): The force seems weak in them.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:42): cekc: practically, you probably won't hit the limit.
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:47): what about variables, how could I do a let x=5 and then a select (x*12)
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:53): cekc: yuo can do that in a procedure.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:54): cekc: It's not really practical otherwise.
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:54): procedures eh?  sweet
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:54): cekc: Apart from prepared statements, that is.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:55): cekc: Prepared statements allow you to use ? as placeholders for parameters you pass in.
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:55): I'm going to be doing it a lot so a procedure might be the way to go
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:56): how about this one, is there a way to turn columns to rows?
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:56): It's a little inconvenient since you have to use them by integral position frmo left to right in the statement.
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:57): or to have a select return more than one row
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:57): cekc: Columns to rows?  You generally don't want to do that.
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:57): let me rephrase better
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:58): cekc: Sometimes you might want to tranform rows to columns for reporting.  That's best done outside SQL in the application.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:58): cekc: But GROUP_CONCAT() can sometimes be helpful.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (09:59): cekc: Columns to rows mainly indicates a design problem.
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (09:59): i better pastebin for this one
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (10:01): I'm trying to do something like this: http://pastebin.ca/180455
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (10:02): but in 1 query instead of 5
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (10:03): the 16*16 will be different every time, but the -10, -20, -30, etc will be different every time
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:03): cekc: That can be done in 1 query simply.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:04): cekc: select yoda-10 as luke1, yoda-20 as luke2, ... from (select (16*16) as yoda) t1;
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:05): cekc: If you want them in a single column, just use UNION.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:05): cekc: or use an appropriate JOIN to allow you to build the set.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:06): cekc: select t1.yoda-v2.val as luke from (select (16*16) as yoda) t1 JOIN (SELECT 10 val UNION SELECT 20) v2 ORDER BY v2.val;
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:09): Hey, with keys...
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:09): Is there a way to insert data into the middle of tables?
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:09): So if I had like 0-5, and I wanted to insert one so that its id was 3.
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:09): But there was already one with id 3.
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:10): How could I shift it right so it would be in the middle, and the others would be shifted?
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:10): Andares: Yes and no.  You don't really want to shift all keys, but you could.
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:10): Xgc, what do I want to do?
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:10): Andares: Use another form of ordering.
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:11): Xgc, what form would that be?
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:11): Andares: What real problem are you trying to solve?
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:11): Xgc, http://s31.us/esperanto/index.php?page=book&id=0
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:11): If you'll indulge me.
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:11): I need a good way of adding/deleting pages.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:12): Andares: Like inserting a page in a book?
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:13): Xgc, exactly!
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:13): Andares: You could link pages into a linked list.
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:13): What?
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:13): I haven't heard of these.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:13): Andares: 1->2->3 ... Then to insert 4 prior to 2, you'd make the next link of page 1 refer to 4 and 4.next refer to 2.
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:14): Xgc, ohhh....
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:15): Xgc, that makes a good deal of sense.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:16): Andares: It's not the most convenient approach for everything.  But it has some advantages.  Many relational databases don't handle these lists too well.
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:16): Xgc, should I make a previous link column too?
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:17): I mean, I need a "Previous" button on the page.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:18): Andares: SELECT ... FROM pages WHERE next='this';
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:18): Andares: You only need next to move back one page.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:19): Just look for the page pointing to the current page.
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:19): Xgc, oh, okay.
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:19): Cool.
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:20): Thanks Xgc.
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (10:20): Night.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:20): Andares: You're welcome.

e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (10:49): xgc: I don't got it yet, but you've given me enough to start with
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (10:50): cekc: Did you try my last query?
e74d913bd351bd508ab06a7c554da354 (10:52): yeah it worked
